bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, December 12, 1952

div1.p: Hench thanks Nogueira for his hospitality during his stay in Cuba. Hench is trying to salvage parts of Building No. 1 and requests Nogueira's assistance.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, December 12, 1952
div1.opener:
December 12, 1952
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
Marti 219, Marianao
Habana, Cuba
My dear Pedro:
div1.p:
I had an uneventful return flight, much more easily accomplished than my
down flight, and was home at 6:30 Sunday evening. Your letter and markings
regarding the fumigation of the wood solved the problem promptly and I brought
the wood home safely. I am delighted to have it.

You will recall that I had not seen, before you packed it, the large heavy ob-
ject. When I opened it I found that it was not the sliding panel but one of
the old shutters. The fact that it is made of tongued-and-grooved wood con-
vinces me that it is one of the original shutters.

There are two items missing which I hope that you can try to salvage at once
with the help of Juan: (1) the other shutter and (2) the solid wood sliding
panel. In all likelihood the other shutter is also the original and I would
urge that you at once salvage it. It does not need to be set up at the window
of Building No. 1 but eventually it can be properly mounted and demonstrated
inside the caseta. Regarding these solid shutters and the description of
the windows in general, see your copy of Senate Document No. 822 (compilation
of Reed's yellow fever papers) pages 83 and 97. Quote from page 83: “These
windows were both placed on the south side of the building...They were closed
by permanent wire screen of 0.5 mm. mesh. In addition sliding glass sash were
provided within and heavy wooden shutters without...” Quote from page 97:
“Both houses were provided with wire-screen windows and double wire-screen
doors...”

I enclose two photographs; one taken for me in 1941, the other in 1948. You
will note in each the ledges beneath and above the window on which the solid
sliding panel slid sideways. In 1941, Zunzunegui was inclined to assure me
that the sliding panel as well as the window shutters were original. Since
the shutters are made of tongued and grooved boards, doubtless they are original
but you will note on page 83 that Reed spoke of “sliding glass sash”. This
means one of two things. (1) That the sliding panel in the photographs is
not Reed's but was made sometime after 1900, presumably when the glass broke, or
(2) perhaps the frame of the sliding panel in the photographs was original
but there were three glass inserts which became broken and were filled with
wood, presumably by Zunzunegui, as shown in the photographs. I should think
that a careful examination of the sliding panel would reveal to you whether
it looked like old 1900 American Army wood or a later product.

Frankly, although I would like to believe that the sliding panel is in part
original, I suspect that it may not be. Nevertheless since it is in our
photographs, copies of which will eventually be made available for demonstration
inside the caseta and since it was used possibly from 1907 on, it is “semi-
historical” and should be saved, at least temporarily.

Pedro, may I urge therefore that at your very earliest convenience, before
Juan or the carpenters destroy the unsaved wood, will you please show them
these two photographs and have them try to find at once the sliding panel
and the other outer wooden shutter, the companion to the one which you so
kindly gave me.

I will sent to you, as soon as I catch my breath, the other two or three items
you want - the photograph from Mrs. Reed's scrapbook showing the six little
yellow fever huts by the LaPlaya railroad track, a photographic copy of
Agramonte's article with the drawings of the buildings, a photostat of a
letter from Reed to his wife with an inked sketch with his plan for Building
No. 2.

In closing this hasty note, may I express to you, in a very inadequate fashion,
and to your colleagues - but first and always to you, Pedro, for your wonderful
hospitality and cooperation all through this affair, but especially last week -
my deep and sincere appreciation. I am most enthusiastic and have many plans
brewing in my head which I shall write you about as soon as I can catch up
with my work.

One more thing. You and I are rightfully the custodians of the souvenir wood.
Why don't we do the thing properly? As soon as I can, I will make a list
of the American institutions and individuals whom I think should have one or
more pieces of the wood. You do the same for your Cuban colleagues. Before
actually presenting any wood to one of these prospective recipients, I will,
however, write to the person or instution and make absolutely certain that
they not only want a piece of the wood but that they will preserve it properly.
Then I will carefully number my pieces (and I will probably need many more which
you can send me in due time) and keep a record of each one as I give it away.
I would strongly suggest that you do the same thing. In that way we can make
a sort of “pedigreed list” of the wood and thereafter there will be not only
less chance of losing track of it but also a better chance to authenticate
any piece that might turn up in someone else's hands. Indeed it has occurred
to me that it would be nice if we could make, without too much expense, a
little “branding iron”, perhaps with the seal of the United States and that
of Cuba side by side, the whole thing about 1 by 1 1/2 inches, so that we could
burn in the corner of each piece of wood this little branding mark which would
authenticate each piece, perhaps burning a number in at the same time. If a
branding mark with the seals of the two Countries would be too expensive, and
it might be, perhaps I could get one something as follows: “C/A - 100”, meaning
Cuban-American Museum, piece No. 100.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
